title: Western International League
text:
The Western International League was a mid- to higher-level <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor league</a> <a href="baseball">baseball</a> circuit in the <a href="Pacific%20Northwest">northwest</a> <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and <a href="Western%20Canada">western</a> <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. Informally known as the "Willy" loop, it operated in 1922, 1937–1942, and 1946–1954. In <a href="1955%20in%20baseball">1955</a>, the league changed its name to the <a href="Northwest%20League">Northwest League</a>, and operated through 2019 as a <a href="Class%20A-Short%20Season">Class A-Short Season</a> loop under that name. In the minor league reorganization of 2021, most Northwest League teams became members of the <a href="High-A%20West">High-A West</a> circuit.
The WIL consisted of teams in the U.S. states of <a href="Oregon">Oregon</a>, <a href="Washington%20%28state%29">Washington</a>, and <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>, and the Canadian provinces of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a> and <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>. It was a <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball%23Reorganization%20of%201963">Class B</a> league through <a href="1951%20in%20baseball">1951</a> and was upgraded to Class A in <a href="1952%20in%20baseball">1952</a>. In its final season in 1954, it started with ten teams in <a href="Calgary%2C%20Alberta">Calgary</a>, <a href="Edmonton%2C%20Alberta">Edmonton</a>, <a href="Lewiston%2C%20Idaho">Lewiston</a>, <a href="Salem%2C%20Oregon">Salem</a>, <a href="Spokane%2C%20Washington">Spokane</a>, <a href="Kennewick%2C%20Washington">Kennewick</a>–<a href="Richland%2C%20Washington">Richland</a>–<a href="Pasco%2C%20Washington">Pasco</a> (playing as "<a href="Tri-Cities%2C%20Washington">Tri-City</a>"), <a href="Vancouver%2C%20British%20Columbia">Vancouver</a>, <a href="Victoria%2C%20British%20Columbia">Victoria</a>, <a href="Wenatchee%2C%20Washington">Wenatchee</a>, and <a href="Yakima%2C%20Washington">Yakima</a>. Three teams did not finish the season (Spokane, Victoria, Calgary). The final champion was the <a href="Vancouver%20Capilanos">Vancouver Capilanos</a>, who swept the <a href="Lewiston%20Broncs">Lewiston Broncs</a> in four games. Vancouver was the first half champion while third-year Lewiston won the second half.
Throughout much of the 1930s and 1940s, its teams were largely unaffiliated with <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">major league</a> <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a>s and provided talent to the strong <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a> of the era.
